element_texts.text:
From Ann
Elynia, Loraine Co. Ohio, June 5th 1862
My Dear Sister, ( to Betsy Conant)

             I have had it in my mind to write to you every day this long time But one thing & another steals away the time I often think of you & Esther & do so want to know not only your external condition & circumstances, but what you think and feel your joys, & Sorrows, your comfort & your trials-
             Can you realise what aged people we are I frequently set myself to ponder the subject and try to feel - but I cannot - that I am as old as people of my age us'd to be when I was young persons as old as my children are were very old folks then
             I can see when I look in the glass how wrinkled I am & can see how Mis Sim' Stearns look'd to me when I went there once, when I was a child, with her mouth all "caved in" it didn't occur to me that I should ever look so
            Perhaps you will laugh at me when I tell you that I have lately got a set of false teeth my children have teased me to - this ten years but I had one tooth remaining & could not feel willing to till a few weeks since that one left me --- & Anna's husband & Isaac persuaded me to have some false ones
            I can eat with them & they have not occasion'd me any pain      My health is very good & I have every privelege & every comfort that I can need and I surely ought to be very thankful I do feel that I am very underserving that I have done very little good in the world to what I might have done & ought to have done

I wish you could be here & see the abundance of Fruit all ours this part of the country - Isaac has on his lot of 5 or 6 acres besides Apple trees - about 80 peach - 40 pear - & 25 or 30 cherry trees full as they can hold of fruit - much the greatest part, set out within 5 years he has some dwarf pear trees not more than 3 or so feet high full of pears down to within 6 or 7 inches of the ground He delights in his orchard & garden & loads it with manure of every kind. 

      Isaac & his family are well they have had six children ---- have buried 3 ---- prospect of another this Summer    Anna & her folks are well she has been without a hir'd girl about a year - to learn her girls to work about house which they were not very likely to do if they kept a girl all the time
      A Soldier return'd here yesterday who has been a prisoner in rebeldom almost a year their prisoners have suffer'd dreadfully ______while these taken by our side have been treated with all kindness - some of them officers at Columbus were allow'd for a while to retain their black waiters! Charles's wife has two Brothers in the Army one of them Sumner Kittridge a Liut. in the 2 Maine Regiment has been a prisoner more than a year Charles's oldest boy is here yet attending School is a very good boy - is very much like his Father    I wish you would tell me something about Joanna & whether she ever rec'd a letter I sent her some months ago
        Tell Esther she must take this as written to her too & write to me________ & I wish you would tell me whether Brother Williams upholds slavery & slave - holders yet ___ I have more folks to write to than either of you so you must not wait for me but both write soon to your affectionate Sister A. M. N.

Milo Aug. 28 1839

Dear Sister, 

               As I have not written any thing? to you Since you went away which can be called a letter I will begin at the beginning. I was sorry that I was up in the potato field when you went away so that I could not say goodbye. I started to come down but found it was too late. I am glad that you had such a good journey, and get along so finely there. The "posy patch" prospers finely.
                The heap by the privy is covered with Ari - colored violets & looketh pretty. The columbine (purple) looked pretty & is sprouting up from the root so as to look pretty next year The foxglove was very profusely covered with flowers & looked very pretty. The mullein pink mother says is very splendid. It really is, & has been and will be for some time to come. The flowers are purple. It looketh very pretty. The two pink roots from Mr. Hoxie's flower profusely & looketh pretty. There is some large double red sweet smelling poppies, and some small Double & bright red poppies very curis leaves etc. which looketh pretty. African Hibiscus & sweet peas blue bells catchfly, candy - tufts marigolds chrysanthemums white & red single poppies as usual.

Our plaquey great new yelloy marigolds are just beginning to flow. We have abundance of White morning glories which looketh pretty & some blue & purple but no red ones. The kittens have grown greatly. and are very pretty.

I suppose you know how we had a tame fox  We have got a tame muskrat what runneth about the house & is about as tame as a kitten, eats milk, parsnips roots, leaves of turnip cabbage beet & bean & pea pods & most everything else.  His castle is in the closet west of the chimney whence he can sully out to the kitchen or pasture.  He hath dug him a hole one entrance being in the closet & the other behind the backroom chimney.  He is the pet, as cleanly as a kitten & not so mischievous.  Upon being called mukky-mukkee,-mukky-he cometh.  We caught a young wild duck & kept it a spell but it would not grow tame & we let it go.  One day Isaac & I went up to Booby Brook fishing & caught 5 great pickerel, 2 eels & duck & one mussquash.  We have got about done haying.  Charles has got a cradle & cradled acres of wheat & 1 acre of oats.
Ann got home last Friday night so in a very good plight.  Only she left 2 of Isaac's books & Mrs Bush's letter tools & ? behind- Isaac came home the twenty sixth of July one weeke before the vacation commenced, & is going back the last of this week I suppose.  He is going back to the same place again  (Mr. Walker’s)  which is a very good place I guess.  He & James F. Walker have corresponded during the vacation. J.F.W is a brother of Mr. Asa Walker about 20 years old I believe, studying law.
Eliab was intending to write some in his letter but he cut his hand today pretty bad so  that he cannot.

I must not write much longer for I have got to write a letter to C.C Barnes and send with this by Mr Wells, who goes I believe by next Friday.  Ellen Lee has been very sick but is better now so that she rides out some.  I wants thee, to write to me, a great long letter pretty quick.  It is 9 o'clock.  I must go to bed.  I shall be sleeping in the morning.  I am afraid.  Good Bye
Lucy. H Metcalfe


                                                                                                                                                                      Joseph M.Metcalf

To my Dear Daughter, Lucy H. Metcalf
We have an opportunity to send letters by Mr Wells but Alas!  I have no time hardly to write as I must fit Isaac away he has but 2 days more to stay at home this time and I have got a bed to make ?other little matters. Are you lonesome when J. I. L & G. are gone away? And are all alone. I hope you have a good page torn
29th Eve.  I guess you don't know nothin about our fox, so one day I was coming home from Gullum when I saw a young fox in the road and I run after him and I caught him & I lugged him home and we dug him a hole out between here & the "posey patch" & he lived & growed prettily and got very tame but 1 day he died and we took off his hide.
From yours affectionate Father.  Joseph M Metcalf.  Good bye.
I have not much time or room to write now but will just say how you'll have a nice time to work & study and read & don't forget my Dear Daughter to spend part of every day in earnest prayer and do become full and not let too much time slip away while you stand talking with your neighbours [Mr J & Marian] it will perhaps be more than list I  have some fear that you will feel lonesome but you need not  if you are well occupied take good care of your health so as to be well and strong and not let Almeda have anything hard to do as she must be very careful or she’ll always be an invalid.   If you rise very early and calculate right  you can do a good deal of work and get time to improve your mind too-Don't get too much engaged about one  thing to the neglect of others.  Be a good girl &  I shall write a good long letter by and by.

Dear Lucy
I suppose P & A are gone so you will get all the letters this time.  I found the boat very crowded, and the sleeping accommodations so poor that I chose to stay on deck as long as there was any lady to stay with me but at last I went down into the cabin and succeeded in finding a place to lay my head though without any pillow:  I slept pretty well, however and rose early enough to see the entrance into Portland, but soon I had to go below again with the sick headache;  I was not sick; Indeed the sea was so very calm that hardly any one was sick.  I had rather a dull day of it being obliged to lie down most all of the time till evening, but then we had a very pleasant time it was bright moonlight and the passage from Bucksport to Bangor you know is interesting.  I found C waiting for me and without stopping we rode out to Moses by moonlight, arrived there at ten o'clock, found them all abed.  Started next morning at six arrived home about noon.  Found the folks well, but wondering greatly at the delay of a day in our coming.  Mothers health is quite good now:  little Olive helps a great deal, I verily believe she does more work than you do.  She is very good natured & tries to please.  Your posy patch exceeds my very highest expectations.  I have gathered a nosegay almost every day of about twenty different kinds-under the window are the scarlet bean and sweet pea, and the two gorgeous marigold and chrysanthemums and several others one in full bloom.  Charles is very busy about his harvesting & the boys have to work very hard.  Eliab cut his hand pretty badly yesterday.  Ann's geranium is alive but it got a real shaking she almost wishes she had left
Mother & Ann Sept. 1839

I went to Sebec to meeting last sabbath, heard Mr Batchelder preach a good sermon. I stopped at the Sabbath school saw about 30 scholars and 5 teachers; quite a contrast to our sabbath school. I am very sorry about Isaac's books and Mr Bush's letters. as soon as James comes home, he must send them in a package to be left at the office in Bangor: it is a pity that James must be at so much trouble about them when they might so easily have been brought but the greatest pity is, that Isaac will be obliged to do without his books for two or three weeks when he really needs them. I have written to Miss Samson by Mr Wells and I want you should ask her whether she has received it and let me know in your next letter. There is always an uncertainty about letters when sent by private conveyance therefore I want you should inquire about it. There is a book that I borrowed of Lydia Lawson, which I wish you would call there and return. Martha and Ellen rode down to see me Monday morning just as we were going to washing but did not get out of the chaise because Ellen was not able to bear the fatigue of getting out and in. Mrs. Hill came along yesterday for mother to go to Mrs. Henry Sargent's s visiting' but when they got to the river they found her gone away, so Mrs Hill spent the afternoon here. Abby is at home and Naomi is not very well. I have scratched down all the news I can think of so good bye
Love to Mr. T and little B.           E.A.

Joseph & I have just sent a little letter to Joseph Hill to carry to you and since then have read: The hymn Book and what shall I call it? not a handsome letter but better than nothing I'm sorry for your Lucy distress about combs but it is of very little consequence--- not knowing the circumstances I am no judge of the case but I should think that the dress for the party too was of very little consequences where there is so many no one is seen you know ------- I say to you Ann & Lucy that I don't feel exactly willing that I don't feel exactly willing that L should stay at Mr. Cutler while Mrs etc are gone without some one else there I dont know any thing but what Mr C is worthy of the utmost confidence but I feel that I should rather she would not & that it is not quite proper but do as you think best I long to have you get home as soon as you ascertain what day your school closes let us know we shall need a great double sleigh to fetch you all three home C. is here now is going back tomorrow morning O he wants you should send a nation at ? by Mr. Joseph Hill I will send the cape and a little pence of money good bye

Joseph seems to enjoy exceedingly, likewise we all, the prospect of your getting smart and coming home to stay while Sam'l is gone into the woods.  He says that as to accommodations they shall be plenty for if needful he can sleep out in the piazza or under the shed that she may have his sleeping room or any way if she can but come.   Partridge, like other cold meats are said to be much better for invalids.  I should think it would do for you to begin to take a little broth ere long.
I'm following your directions in regard to advising Almeda about fixing up etc I did in my Blundering inadvertent way so speak as to offend or rather grieve but I'm sure I did not mean it she sometimes takes more than you mean you know.  She feels that you & perhaps I have too much thought about fashion stores.  It is true that in the world we shall have tribulation and that the more we live above and regardless of the world & place our trust & happiness in Christ where only here peace is found the better it is for us, we are apt to seek worldly gratification & think we have it when if fairly analyzed we would find a considerable mixture of something else.
I think a little season spent here with Joseph would be not only pleasant but instructive to both you and Lucy.  Lucy must get well fast and come home & what a fun time we will have here in Josephs cozy warm room.

Arrived home in safety before it was quite as dark as Egyptian darkness it began to grow dark the fog was so very thick soon after we left Bradford  from a MisBlunder  or something about the  Ostler we were detained longer than John intended.  My back did ache before I got there, but got nicely rested.  Felt considerable apprehension about getting home in safety on account of the darkness, but we got along nicely & all was well.  There was no very striking  appearance of displeasure on the countenance of Joseph  or any of the rest but they all with one accord began to say they were sorry to see me and "kinder" scold me for not staying longer with you, that they could do without me just as well as not, i.e as they, better than you could. So that the danger seems to be that I shall  not be wanted nowhere no how.  I do want to know how you are this very day & how you are every day.  If you are really getting strong-gaining in health & strength everyday.  I should think that in a few days after Almeda gets there you could dismiss your Nurse & thereby get along with less expense and more satisfaction.  Almeda is very kind hearted and capable, only like me she is apt to be a little negligent and forgetful-------If you see Eliab tell him not to get some paper to make some envelopes as Joseph requested some time ago and not to get at present Harpers new Monthly Magazine but give no more than 20 cents a number Isaac says that is the price.
J.M to every body----if to be found in your precincts and you can bring em conveniently & spare em as well as not I should desire you, to visit:  Ann to bring Telemaque, la Henriade , French testament, "Scotts poetical works of the last Minstrel" Greenleafs arithmetic, if you have it, key it to Emersons second part, 1/2 quire  or one quire  of envelope paper white would not be preferred unless equally as cheap, each of these commissions, to be deferred or omitted if more convenient 2 partridges were presented to me for which not having further use I transmit one to you

Mother  Hampden
30 May 1850

                                                                                                     Hampden 30th May 1850

My Dear Children
I will just speak a word or two to tell you that I arrived safely before dark-rather rough, muddy travelling but I was not very indeed tir'd found Lucy-getting better she says-but she is rather slim.  She rode out a little way today tho' she cannot sit up more than an hour at a time she has been very sick-but begins to have a little appetite now-she thinks she shall soon be considerably better-she probably took cold and she has worked too hard & I don't believe  she will be so well as she was before for some time-Sam'l got a skien of black worsted for card & four tassels for the pall cloth-at 1/apiece the skien, 10 cents I don't think it will take near all the worsted if there is enough left  to foot a pr stockings I'll take it-if they wish.
I hope you will all of you, encourage and assist Mr Temple in his Labor of Love----I do advise & labor & strive with J Dolen he must be car'd for---prayed for and arrested in his downward course.  How much good he may do in the world if now he should turn and set out in a right course.
I'm afraid you wont all be faithful about getting pay for preaching---Sam'l will speak to Mr Cutts about carrying cheap-think he will for a

dollar a trip______________
I wish you would have Lucy come down and clear up Josephs room  here so that Albina need not have too much to do ___________& do you Isaac stir up and fix the straw in Josephs bed-because of my sore finger I didn't do anything to it for some time-I shall be thinking about you all-take good care of Jose-and Charlie-and be good all of you.
My love to Mr Temple tell him he of good courage God WILL prosper his work.
Lucy says, she began to get better as soon as she saw me coming-take care and write to me every day.
Lucy says tell Mr. Temple we would be pleased to have him call here tis just a pleasant walk Mr Wm said he is coming down some time with some of the students.
Sam'l is just going, I can't write any more.  Goodbye
A M Metcalfe

Hampden June 10

My Dear Children
I write a little to let you know, & because I want to know, whether I ought to  go/come home.  L is better rode up to Bangor last week and then was not so well-went to meeting in the forenoon Sunday.  Monday was not able to sit up an hour-she seems a little better every other day-don't appear to have any fever hardly now is I think on the whole convalescent and wants to go to Milo to see you all very much, will as soon as next week I think if she is able.  Till she is considerably better she will need me or somebody here-now I want you should all tell me what I ought to do-I don't feel just right to be away from J so long-(not that I do him any good when I am there as Isaac does every thing) and I fear that Albina  has too much to do to take care of so many all you lot of boys & Mr Temple-I think your couple of hours per diem Isaac might be very acceptable to her-have you set up a bed in the east chamber or anywhere  Lucy has given me some stuff for Charley  a dress so Albina better not get any till will come-tell Almeda make up Lucy's dress but not fix her bonnet till we come if she has not-Lucy you know is good for telling how every thing should be done if she is half sick-does Almeda want I should get a pr

shoes for Lucy.  Samuel has spoken with Mr Cutts about carrying up the students.  He will carry for a dollar a trip (he said he'd give 2 or 3 dollars besides.) S will pay part of it I guess.  I am going to bring up Lucys rug for Albina to look at before she makes hers, better not colour her old dress.  Great rain yesterday I'm 'fraid the interval  is all flood again, write soon tell me how you all get along-take care of Josie & of Charlie.
If Lucy can only get well enough she & I will come up with cab ourself alone (leave Jane to keep house) but I fear she wont she is so unwell yesterday & today-but perhaps she'll be better tomorrow in haste A.M.M
I myself, Lucy, am at present this afternoon feeling better than I did, without hardly knowing why, except that Jane bought me some beautiful young checkerberry leaves, which I have munched with much gusto.  Mother and I are having a nice time.  I feel sort of selfish and guilty to keep  her here away from Josie so long, but I don't want her to go till I get well enough to go with her, which I hope will be soon.  Samuel is about concluding to go into the Mill as Hathorne is very anxious to have him, and the prospect of an appointment as surveyor is slight this year) for $40.00 per month, until it starts by night, and after that at the old wages.  Jane goes to school, has some new books, gets her lessons well, and I guess tries to do her best in school, but is the same noisy fly away thing as ever out of school.  Though she helps nicely out of school - Albina must not flatter herself about a dress for Charlie-it is only

part of an old dark gingham dress of mine which mother said would answer for him,  and the rest of which I am making up for Jane.  I want to come to Milo dreadfully.  Think I should go into summer quarters there with the rest of you, if I had not a husband and Jane to look after.  How I shall set you to making "horse stable carpets" when I come, Albina.  They are handsome.  Mother forgot to bring her parasol and desires some of you to make a suitable measurement of the quantity of silk necessary to cover it, and communicate the same soon.  Mother wishes after a suitable and sufficient inspection of the rug carpet, you would send your opinions individually and collectively as to the propriety and expediency of getting a new one.  I am lolling on the bed-The doors are open into the dining room, where "Pa and Ma" and Jane are eating supper.  They'll fix me up a mess of coarse bread and slops suppose, by and by-yah.  They treat me pretty well though considerin.  Tell Almeda to hurry and get Lucy's dress done before I come, and we'll conclude about the rest of her clothes.  
Samuel says tell Joseph Hitcher is defaulted. Thurston is in the way-continued for judgement. Thurston hopes to get a chance to go west and go into the coal trade.  Brandywine is being sheathed.  Senator being shod - could not be done when the other repairs were made last spring, water was so high.  Henry Brown has lately come into possession of a new son.  Samuel is 'bout ready to go-do write a great deal-for Mothers sake if you don't for mine.  Good night.
Lucy

Thursday Nov 22nd 9 1/2 evening

My Dear Daughter
I have just received your kind letter I wrote a little to you in the same with a bit of a letter to Eliab  about the 14th or 15th which perhaps you have not received-I thank you very much for your letters and for your invitation to visit etc--------I really want to see you in your fine house am glad you like it so well.  I hope your health will be good and you will have nothing to hinder your enjoying much happiness therein.
You ask when I will visit you I think I had better not yet a while you will probably for considerable time  nowadays, had a good deal of company and we shall both enjoy it better if I wait till midwinter or so or certainly till after Isaac comes home-I have had letters from him since this month came in (he a good boy isn't he) I think he will when Joseph gets ready to come home come and wait upon him home and then I can go to Hampden when he goes along back.  
Almedas foot is better so that she can go about  to see her neighbors on crutches & about house on them.  She went twice to Grafton Fresh today, thier child is very sick____I almost think hard of Joseph was very disappointed 2 or 3 lost mails, he has not written to me only once since he went away.  I feel very anxious about him .  I want to know how long he means to stay & whether is getting better___I don't think Jane could mend that cloak he had last winter.  It's too much solid and too small.  I can fix her warm enough I guess unless it is very much colder Saturday than it is today-I hardly know whether to send Janes old hood.  I am thinking that I can take the two and rip and color them and make me one that figured silk you know is pretty good but if you can make use of it for her I will send it.

 I expect I can sell my wool here at Cushing for 27 cents a pound and shall have money enough to get a cloak.  So don't trouble yourself any thing about it at present. You will have enough to do about these days- too much I’m afraid - you are good kind daughter to think so much about me when you have so much to do-I guess I can fix my muff  over well enough, don’t you think I can.

you tell of being abed apart of the forenoon, have you not been as well as normal________I haven't anything very special you know to keep me in one place more than another so if any of you are not well at any time and I can be useful to you I can start my  stumps in a that time if you but let me know but if all are well____it seems to me I had better be here at present but I shall probably write again soon____shall have a letter from Joseph tomorrow I guess___Do you write again soon & tell us how whether you receive Jane "safe and sound".
Angella Everett has got a son so has Mrs Richer & Mrs M. Clench & I don't know how many more___Mrs Aicken has  gone on the river to work. She dismissed her nurse before her babe was a fortnight old-they have absolutely nothing to eat except what C furnishes they have had about all his wages now and he doesn't again to pay him any till winter they will not move away from Almeda this winter & I don't see hardly how they are going to live till next fall to say nothing about building a house. 
23rd I am some afraid from what  Isaac wrote in his last letter that he will not come any further than Waterford if Joseph does not come home but I shall feel very sadly about it if he does not-Joseph I suppose will think he had better not-If I don't have a letter from Joseph today what shall I do
Albina has cut and made a vest for Charlie, out of his old blue coat all only I am making the button hole .  Charlie sits on the floor before me making a Cob home has got it 4 cobs high in regular order his Cobs have roll'd under the stove so he goes round to the wood box and gets a stick to poke them and without asking any help he is a persevering little fellow.  I am about getting my carpet now or rather a part of it.  I want Eliab to get me 3 or 4 pounds of Cotton twine such as weavers use for loomers at Mrs Bughees or I can't get all my rags  none have sent what warp & have got to Mrs Summer to weave shall make another piece if I get some more warp. I don't believe you can read this, I wish I had some ink.

Saturday

Charles was intending to go to Bangor the day we came up or the next day but for the death of Mr. Sargents little boy, he could not of course _____ But assist & sympathise they seem to feel this was very much.  Mr S says he had buried a Brother & Father & Mother but never felt grief like this.
I brought away thinking if Josephs one of Isaac shirts  an old one but perhaps he would mean it some more so I'll it back.  I don't think it best to get very coarse cloth for Josephs shirts.  I should think such as you get for Sam'l if I want you should get about 5 yds for me also.
I wish you would write to Ann soon I suspect the Mr & Mrs Hopkins she is with are very uncomfortable folks to live with and are mean.  I think that she does not & can not enjoy herself there______ you know Josephs stern philosophy he wrote to her that she had better not come home ________ but I feel bad to have her so situated.  She is very apt to enjoy herself wherever she is comfortably situated ________ It is hard to be a strong away from all ones friends _______ I wish she would come home and stay and be happy____ Joseph takes his drip sheet in the morning  is as well as he was, he was no more fatigued than I expected - he sleeps in the large bedroom__________ I am afraid that with all his philosophy he will be unable to keep up his spirit in the long days so monotonous so little to excite or pleasantly interest - however he's getting ahead right right smart I tell him he has just walked across the room, alone except this comes where before he left W. he used to go walk with 2 canes 3 times the length of the Piazza & repeat 1 operation several times pr diem.

I sent the old shirt old crape for duster ball of yarn to toe off your stocking, will send you some more when we have some wool carded -- Charlie is a touch smart little fellow is out these cold days mercury down to zero or 2 or 3 above half way down to the barn & stays out trying to saw now under the shed with out any mittens or cap he can open the door so he can go out and in when he pleases -- when Joseph sits down on the lounge he spring along to lift up his feet -- I have news on mother hopes to tell you you know we have "Society Meeting at the corner the only meeting held in town now -- & whereas there are at put on by some half dozen now they have increas'd very much and prayer meeting, every Sabbath evening somewhere in the neighborhood Some of the time at Almeda's this evening at Mr Bumps there were 30 there -- I have not been to meeting today or evening as I thought Jos had rather I would not -- Almeda thinks that Lucy has obtained a hope you know she has been very thoughtful a good while may we not hope that God is about to display the riches of his mercy towards us -- not for our own prayers and tears but for his great names sake -- I have felt unusual heavyness of thirst with earnest pleading tears & sleeplessness 2 or three months past when thinking of this town and of Charles in particular -- It seemed to me we were all cast off and forgotten and deserv'd to be -- But O the tender mercy and long suffering of God - Pray for us - for me
Monday Evening 25th
If you have any letter from Isaac send it and send back Ann's letter if convenient -- write a good long letter & tell me how Mrs. Crosby does &c -- If Charles hands you any money take it & I will tell you what to do with it next time I send those old gloves you can let Jane wear? them or turn them for her they are too small for Lucy-- Had a letter from Mariah Stevens to night

17th May 1850
My Dear Daughter
As we confidently expect you to be here next week I must try to think up some errands to plague you with before you come -- & by the way Isaac sent to you to get a carpet now I think and Joseph thinks if you have not already purchas'd it that you had better not quite get at any rate -- My rag one is now done I have not yet seen it but doubtless it will look well enough for us -- A carpet you could get and send up after you go back if tis thought best -- but I should like to have you get some carpet thread when or no -- And -- If tis perfectly convenient for you you may get a shawl for me such as we talked of & pr of good kid gloves -- I have made a single bed but have got no narrow sheets for it and shall want some very wide sheeting or some quite narrow & sew it together the very cheap narrow cloth  I suppose would do would'nt it but no matter whether I have it soon or not -- and moreover if Sam'l should from any course conclude not to have the cow this instrument to be null & void -- so far as to getting things you may understand by the grease spot on this letter that I have got a very sore finger have to keep it done up in a rag a ""surround" expect the nail will come off
Mr Temple has been here two weeks past went away to Mr. Furbers today he is a real nice little man all the folks about town seem to be pleas'd with him I have just been to light old Mrs Cutts to bed She has been making a visitation at Uncle Henry's

She went there last tuesday the pleasure of her visit was somewhat prolong'd favorably by the rain altho' she said she did not mean to get home till Saturday night uncle Henry got very nervous - I don't know but I shall -- she came here this morning will visit Almeda tomorrow
How cold and rainy it has been the water so high & ground so wet that C. has not done any of his sowing or planting Isaac says that he thinks of going away somewhere in about a week I hardly know how we shall get along without him Josephs new; to have him or some other man at hand most of the time
I hope you will not fail of coming up next week -- but he I do suppose wants to be thought to be in business if he can find any to do if he cannot of course he's better be here
I hope you'll bring up your rug if tis not too much trouble I should very much to see it
I do so want to see my Dear Eliab why dont he come home Tell him that he han't been home this Any time I want he should come and tell me all about Miss Lamp Stone and all the girls
Moreover Joseph wants Eliab or Sam'l to get a small bag of crack'd wheat also some wheat or graham meal bring up or send according to convenience
It is, and be it, hereby understood that all and singular of the aforesaid and beforementioned writings and sayings of A.M. Metcalf which do in any way or form relate to the subject or matter of "Carpet" are undoubtedly and unconditionally null and void . I.S.M.

CHARGE YE get NO Carpits - 
{Vito I.S.M.}   J. M. his x actory mark
delays are dangerous.
at least wait till we see mine: Joseph says Isaac is a Janus. Delay not.
MIND yrs M a v W.

Dear Daughter how did you get home why haven't you let us know, & whether you found Sam'l alive and well, and whether he was glad to see you I've a lot of things I want to say to you that I ought to have said when you were here but forgot besides a great many that have occur'd to me since but I cant think of any thing that is just right to say now, or cant think of it, I'm so confus'd with finishing off four other letters for Jess and me
C. handed you 3,00 with which I believe they want you to get 20 yds, 4 cloth, 6" good for shirts with linen (4 or 5' yds)- skein unbleach'd threat & shirt buttons, also Table Cloth & crash if convenient for you to get them and if it was not to much plaque Eliab so when he has so much to see to I should want you to get some a little money which will be to C's Albinas credit for eggs and get a 1/2 doz knives & forks she needs 'em but no matter you all have enough else to do or ought to have
ya want 10 yds of the 4 cent Cotton Cloth so you had better get a whole piece 
Do write after I want to know how you get along everyday

Mother July
13th July 1850
My Dear Daughter we receiv'd your letter & kerchief by Mr Furber today- John looks very thin am fraid he studied to hard but perhaps work will fat him up again
I am sorry Isaac has got to hurry away so that he cant stop, any  with you_ I hardly know how we shall get along with out him_ Joseph has now got a bad Cold and Cough what shall I do for him_ believe I shall try Thoroughwort Candy
How I should have deceas'd if I had been with you when you were eating your Beef- very cheap food & very good 
I wish I could have heard Mr. Temples account of Milo if he calls to see you give my love to him_ he is a very good Man very much indeed devoted to the cause of Christ I think he has already been the means of accomplishing great good in Town_ Mr Sargent (uncle Henry) says there is no other man that would do as much good to come here & preach now as he would_ we don't consider our turnips hardly eatable now but will send if he can carry conveniently_ was very sorry about your veil we did not diskiver it til after Lucy was gone 
Our Peas in blossom a week ago do to eat in a week or so I guess raspberries dont begin to be ripe- you must try to find something more important to think about than eating I hope you dont spice your mince pies too much & beware that you dont eat too much of them- they'll be quite a rarity at this time of year but wont keep long will they I wish I had one- we expect to have Alfred John Dolen Boabar & Welch boy here this week Joseph and all of us rather think now that it would be better for Charles to take care of Joseph and have more help on the farm he could get at any

one man after Haying for he could have time to do nearly half as much work as he does now I hope Eliab can come home when he leaves Browns and spend the winter he never would regret it I think it would be such a comfort to Joseph but he says that Eliab must not that he ought to be in better business if he dont go to work somewhere that he ought to go off to Cuba, N. Orleans on somewhere and learn something I doubt whether Alfred can be contented here long
I guess you'll just ride up here and stay a week or so in the first part of August shan't you now think of it & I guess you'll think you will_ Isaac has just been out and brought in some Peas big enough to eat they were sow'd in the 1st of june I would send you a teacupfull only I suppose they are plenty enough in the market_ Joseph says if you have a right good chance send Smellees Phylosephy of Naturat History and a good specimen of Sweet Briar- in your Book you have a specimen of Rosa Lucida mark'd R. rubiginosa, which is sweet briar such you have in your garden, therefore preserve specimen to take place under your label, we will insert, lucida, perhaps milida.
Joseph says dont be in a hurry about your Book but fix it up nice not have it homogenious mess
now forget to come home- tell Mr. Temple there was a large Bible Class last Sabbath a wish they could have had a better Teacher than I think Mr. Short is- the largest number of S. S. Scholars that I have ever seen-O how I wish we could have a good faithful preacher here all the time the I suppose we shall have preaching all the time- Mr Lee was here today said he thinks that the Baptists wouldn't be willing to have Congregational preaching 3/4 of the time the feel a little jealous- Mr. Owen said he would have Mr. Page if he could if he had to pay himself but that is only report perhaps he didn't say it

My Dear children,
Isaac won't let me write a word in his letter nor let me see it. So Joseph says I must write and explain the Mushment - He has got mush enough for two breakfasts & meal enough for 2 or 3 days so if you are not coming as soon as Wednesday or Friday at farthest - he want you send meal and mush stuff by stage soon (& be sure that you bring up  the letter Isaac has just written to you) We kept looking for you all days last week.
We are making a strenuous effort to raise some money to pay for preaching. Ch. & Alme I.J. & myself mean to make out some 15 or 20 Dollars & if you have anything to give for any such purpose I am thinking that it is perhaps your duty to help poor miserable Milo - The H. M. Society will furnish just as much as we will pay ourselves i.e. will pay one half - will send a missionary to abide with us probably from among the graduating class at Bangor. & tis thought that the students will (each one a sabbath) supply us with that time if they can come and go without expense to themselves. Cannot Mr. Cutt be induced to bring them up very cheap - and cannot you induce other [Miloites that were, to help - Wm. & Charles Dennell etc etc
Mrs. Livermore  had my carpet done all but - a week or bottom part torn off- so it not brought?

1850
My Dear Daughter      I expect the time is not far distant when Dear Joseph will be unable to feed himself. Can you realise at all what a trial it must be to him xxxxxxxxxxxx how would you or I feel to be obliged to take all our food from anothers hand xxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxx To enable him to do it a little longer I want you or Eliab  to get if you can a silver spoon small desert, or very large teaspoon one twice as large or little more than twice as large as your teaspoon perhaps. He dont go out to eat with the family now he can with great exertion take a tumbler from the table to his mouth. He cannot take up his teacup of milk I wish we could get a very light tumbler or mug with a pretty large handle to it - that he could hold between his fingers and the palm of his hand. I have not said anything to him about feeding him (I dont love to) tho' doubtless he has thought about it - I have been very sorry I did not bring home with me a little spittoon like yours it would have been very convenient for him - If you come up fetch yours perhaps. It seems as if Eliab wasn't here any hardly. It would be such a gratification to Joseph to have you come & stay a week or two that I think you will not find it in your heart to stay away so long xxxxxxxx How strange, how unacountable it is that Joseph can be so patient so cheerful.
If you can get such a spoon & tumbler or mug you need say nothing about it only send or bring them soon, perhaps he would not like if if he knew I sent but I do think it best to get them if I can              in haste.
I'll take the responsibility ie. I'll pay for em.

am somewhat disturbed at the idea of your washing and working so very smart, beware, take care of yourself, you are not made of iron dont be so solicitous, or so particular about your work so as to endanger your health, would you be willing to suffer months or years of pain & anguish rather than that your work should be delayed or your house hold affairs should be disarranged? remember now, & be good.
21 Albina has got H. train'd to it so that she is really a great help to her about her work when there is no other here she does nicely, is very quiet, kindhearted and ready to do a service to any one 24th.
29th The "Bag" come to hand last night the things all right and well very much obliged to you & Eliab for all your trouble. Albina says she has got one dollar for her eggs which she will send towards paying for what you got for her [above this] Crash buttons etc. if you got a "great many funds" of Eliab, you can hand it to him. Charles was exceedingly gratified, pleased, & delighted, and grateful for Eliabs letter and its contents had an opportunity to send the money right to Dover the same day,  Early in the morning of the same day he offer'd to sell all his cows & young cattle to Mr. Monroe for 110$  (4 cows, 4 two years old) but Monroe would give but 99$  so they did not trade, he means to sell 2 cows if he has a chance kill one hiefer & sell one rather has sold one for Steers to John to pay him for his work

  What shall I do to Joseph because he will read and all the time from morning till night, in the evening and while he eats even. Tell Eliab I have been feasting on tomatos with great zest and comfort "they is good"

Cedar Grove Sept. 1850

         My mind is much impress'd with the importance of having, efficient, trusty, & energetic, Captains in Schooner Brandywine & Senator. Having propos'd in a recent interview with Mr. Furber certain schemes to that end. It is perhaps inexpedient to dwell upon the subject at present.
 I understand that S.D. Thurston is about commencing in the Coal business. Will not this furnish to Schooner Brandywine tolerable profitable employment, to which by her structure she is well adapted?

Mrs. Lee returned day before yesterday without visiting yourself as I am told.

Care should be exercis'd in dealing with quaker  a member of that shrewd Sect had a Vessel at sea which was wrecked, on hearing of its loss he immediately wrote as follows to a Broker with whom he had previously had some indefinite conversation about insuring it  "Friend - if thou hast not filled up the policy I spake to thee of, thou needest not, as I have heard from the Vessel"  The Broker catching at the chance of securing a premium without a risk immediately filled out the policy and Sent it to the quaker Saying that he had completed it before receiving the letter. Cedar Grove  Nov 7th 1850
Dear Folks
What for you so cruel to me, that you did not let me hear from any of you by Wednesday Mail  you Almeda, surely, if none of the rest ought to know the heart of a Mother, when I left Lucy so sick how do you think I could wait a week before I hear from her. & now its after 8, we begin to think that Ann wont come today we've Strain'd our eyes looking for her. If there is n't a letter what Shall we do.  7 oclock well your letter has "arriv'd" Ive felt better on that score, but Joseph & Albina especially was very much disappointed that Ann did n't come, we also had a letter from Isaac, his place of residence at present is Manchester N.H. 2 or 3 of our last letters he had not arrived. I think, Ann, that you had better come home Monday I am inclined to think that Almeda with Jane, can do all that is necessary to do it will not be more then when I was there last summer, & the more still & quiet it is the better for Lucy, & the faster she will get along, So she can come home. If her cough continues any at all I would like to recommend to steep slowly in a coverd dish some thorough {unclear} let it be very strong take a teacup full or nearly that put in loaf sugar enough to make it a palatable Syrup & take a teasponfull or so when she needs it not refuse it if she really thinks it good for her even if it does not taste good
I said to you all only Sam'l so I guess I'll direct to him.

Your children Almeda are getting along all nice apparently ever so much better, probably, than if you were with them, I guess Lucy makes quite a housekeeper probably she will not get your sewing done but you can soon do that when you return. James complain'd a little of a lame stomach did n't want to go to prayer meeting nor have Lucy. C. & Albina went up to the school house but as it happen'd there was no meeting Mr Wilson has not returned to this town or had not last night. Tis suppos'd that he can have the Carver house 3/4 mile from The Village if he wants it
Report says that Mr Robert Cutts has a very bad knee has to have watchers every night Some suppose he will be under the necessity of having his limb taken off but probably Sam'l is better informed about it than we are - Charles will go to The Village monday after noon Do come Monday Tis enough to make a smarter woman than Lucy nervous at least to have have 3 such great smart Maids to Manage as Nurse Almeda & you. If Almeda gets corner'd she can call on Mrs Finnigan Lucy must think & be careful of herself
Mrs Polly Sargent is sick - had the Dr., is some better now Inflamation of the Bowels - worked to hard & took cold
I told Lucy to bring her washing down here & I'd help her do it but she wash'd herself before I knew it such things as she thought would be needed, wash'd her floors, & Iron'd yesterday

Friday morning my Dear Daughter Lucy reflect much on the goodness of God how in affliction he has remember'd many he has given you a loving call to draw near to him, to live nearer to him all your live O may all consider it , he warned by it, and try to think more of the glory that shall shall be reveal'd and less of the  foolish vanities and fashions of this perishing world
Lissie says she dont care about reading the Childs Book on The Lord any more, for it dont say any thing about God hardly & she likes best to read Books that have in them a great deal about praising God
James has come to go with the letter good bye

Cedar Grove                          Milo 6th Aug. 1850

My Dear Daughter, Will you please to however that this ink is very poor so that I can hardly make my marking legible to myself & yesterday I did for Joseph with this same pen and ink mark a letter to Mr. Isaiah Dole do you think he can read it, if he cant wont it be good enough for writing such a scrawl as he did to Joseph.

  Well I give it up for a bad job & must stop writing unless with a pencil till we can get some ink - what a long spell of heat Monday weather we do have - but the corn, the vines and tomatos do grow finely.
Now are you coming up or are you not we do want you should come very much, but if you cant or if you wont, let us know it so that we need'nt strain our eyes out alooking. Charles has not done haying yet lest he should fail of having his money to pay for help in haytime he paid his help beforehand Mr. Boabar, Richer, & Welch boy therefore get disappointed of them all but Richer who has come now a fortnight after the time but they'll get done next week I suppose. I strongly purpos'd to send you some raspberries but all the folks said I could not.
  Aint you glad I have borrow'd a bottle of Almeda's ink dont forget to send us a bottle of neat good ink, i.e. tell Eliab to fetch us some. 7th. We have just received your letter good girl to write but I do feel disappointed that you are not coming home & can hardly make myself believe it it seems as if Lucy was old enough to keep house one week & you & Jane come up you complain about not writing but I thought we had written to

since we had had one from you but perhaps not I pity your lot in regard to L. but suppose there is no help for it - her mother us'd to be just so, 'tis constitutional.
Josie says we did get up quite a letter she and I & did send it in due form & that you had given us no credit therefor we cannot conveniently write to Eliab at this time & therefore Josie wants you should request him to get a few quines of paper Some ink & a pr of shovel & tongs four cheap [unclear] to put on the old care table and bring them up when he comes & if convenient for you you may get for me a skien of unbleach'd cotton a 45 spool -- I wish you would write me more particularly about your health you may if you please furnish Eliab some money to get these things and charge it to me or if Sam'l is not to busy to get them - as to Joseph's being better I cant perceive any difference from week to week but I do suppose he is as he has been very gradually growing more helpless it is difficult for him to get his food & drink to his mouth I can hardly bear to think of it, but the probability is that he will by & by be unable to do it - His voice seems some weaker than it us'd to be  he cant well wash himself now

Aug. 8. 1850

Me to her cc. Joseph to Lucy

 Write hey? write? Bless you indeed we went what we thought to her for us, very much a letter which you have not taken the least notice of nor acknowledged it at all. We were so busy making Shirts & mending coats for Alfred that we had no time to write by him. Aint coming hey?  I wanted you to somewhat particularly as well as immaticularly about Botanicing & finishing Herbarium et. but I have all along I shrewdly suspected you hadn't ought to, if you conclude to think to guess how I shall - J. is getting well hey?  I authorize you to give the reports an emphatic contradiction wherever it may spread thankth  your agency I believe it to be entirely correct - a very natural mistake on Alfred's part, perhaps, from seeing me "peart" in Botanicing  etc. Prof. Shepard hey? well that'll do. You haint learnt to spell Tuesday yet hey? yah! green pearsley hey? so do me & beans too
                H.A. Moore is going off west hey? If upon careful enquiring you ascertain that to be the fact & can do it without troubling yourself too much please get and give her for me to carry away with her
        If you can find it "Lady of the Lake", Handsomely printed extra binding gilt edge. She is one of my most highly esteem'd friends the number of which is small    Jane is waiting to carry this.
I have been fixing lots of things for your historical scrap book and will send them by Eliab.

[left-hand side and top] 15th  We had a letter from Ann last night. written 5 Oct. said she should start the next monday. Enclosed is ten dollars which Charles wishes you to hand to Eliab which he may place to C's account also the 2 dollars for Albina's things.  C intended to write a letter to Eliab & expected to send him 25,00, but did not sell his Steers, but thinks it will be much more to his advantage to keep  then as he has got much poor fodder suitable for Cedar Grove.

                                                                                                                                    Oct. 8 1850 young little Joseph has commenced giving lessons in Arithmetic. He will very much need the Map of the U.S. when they begin Geography. am sorry he could not have contriv'd to get it here before now. If you have any convenient opportunity I wish you would send it Morever I [crossed out] wish you would let Jane dig up a lot of that Dock root in back of your house & send it up if there is a good chance I want it to put in some syrup for Joseph there is not much of it growing about here [crossed out]

now we did'nt have a single letter yesterday. I thought besure we should get one from you & one from Ann.

  I expect you are to hurried with work as usual that you can hardly spare time to breathe. But, if you dont heed my warning you may have to repent that's all.
12th Almeda & I called at Mr. Rickers the other day. Imagine to yourself a pen or box 14 ft square with a roof to besure but the side boarded so loosely that you could think your hands out anywhere thro' the interstrees between the boards a table 3 old chairs a chest & a little bit of a cupboard. I suppose they have not had bread or meet more than half the time this summer - with a nurser babe. She has had to (as her children went to school except the two youngest) & Edward to help run after the cattle pick greens and berries to supply their hunger till the beans etc. got grown & had to go as far for it all as from here to the river - bende to watch a herd of cattle and keep them off of their field

as they have not any fence so that she had no time to make cloth, (of the little wool she had), to clothe her family which they very much need- but since their crops were gathered in she has worked & has got a good long web of cloth done which will fit them all up nicely - he rais'd 100 bushels of oats & their prospects brighten considerably  - now for the brightest side of this picture which I suppose you will say is not very bright, they all seem very healthy and happy, more than we can say of probably any millionaires, five boys bounding about in joyous boisterous mirth, any of them fit for Governor, possibly  some future day. I guess I've said enough about the Rickers.
14th  How I do want to see Ann. Send her along home about as quick as she gets there. Albina talks of sending you 2,00 to get her things that she told you about & says you have a list of them.

  Mrs. Lee says she did not come by your house that they thought some of riding down there but now so circumstances that they could not have stay'd more than half an hour was very sorry etc. Mrs. Hannah Brown Morrell died at Watersville, or somewhere away there, was brought home, burried yesterday. Is not it sad & distressing that we have no prospect of any preaching if you know where Mr. Temple is do think of us, & pray for us. Mr. Lee & Mr. Sargent are both going away what shall we do - not a Male member of the Congregational Church left in town excepting your Father Furber & he is going

[bottom of page, upside down] The Brandywine you say goes a fishing. Do you look out that the Brandywine is paid in to your hands. The reputation of the Dear Islanders for honesty etc. is nearly equal to that of Algerenes or Arabs and has been well sustained in my dealing with them. What has Margaret gone to Boston for. Have you heard from Hannah Moore. If to be found in your precint, please send at your convenience with Cowper Les Aventures de Telemaque and cloth for another pr of Cotton Shirts
[right-hand side] my letter & Joseph's seems to interfere a little

Oct. 14th J.M. he - says that your Dock root is probably is probably not the right kind that usually grows in the edge of water. Charles what has been thrashed = 16 bushels he has sold a cow for 15, & a little Heifer for 11, cash down &  no grumbling. Almeda has lost her valued yearling Heifer suppose it is gone off with some drove to Brighton. Mr. Henry B. Sargent has swapped farms with a man called Caton and intends to move as soon as the ground freezes onto the farm at the Corner South of Abner Hoxies where Wm. Ferrer & Elder Lord live. Jeanette Hasket has been married to Walter Starkvant her Father has bought him a farm in Dover & moved onto it.  Mr. Lee means to move to Brownville this week. Joseph L. Sargent has got a son. Mr. Hartnett is sick

    yours of Sept. 30 was doubtless received. I am greatly enraged about the schooner Brandywine & I am afraid you have poor security for her comings from now to the first of Jan.  a Capt. seems to be a highly important appendage to a Vessel. If a suitable and satisfactory one is not provided for the Senator. Lansil the Cooper on Broad Street being extensively acquainted with Seafaring men, is a good man to enquire of towards finding one. So is Joseph Bryant Esq. the Lansils are a very large & smart family. Several Several of them among the smartest of coasting Captains & the youngest ones are doubtless to acquire renown in the same way. I did not know that Romulus Haskins was Deacon, how scandalously you misspell Superb,  in speaking of your squashes - "Serpent " - yarr!
  I'll do what I can to send some of them down there

[left-hand side] Send Albina's things by Ann if convenient. If there is money enough she wants you should get cord & tassels for her curtains in the Sitting Room - like mine.

I am so glad you are coming right along soon But how can I have Ann go right away again. Tis midnight & very Cold I must not stop to write much, but I want to say to you that Joseph ought to have another pr of good warm Blankets you know my old bed clothes are not so good and warm He dont want I should get any but you can tell Eliab & do what you think best. If you will get you a pr & bring em with you I will pay for them as fast as I get able. I have put 3 or 4 old Comforters on his bed instead of a Mattress. I intended to make some more but I have not been able to do scarcely any thing since Ann went away for want of time. I have been so taken up that I have neglected or forgotten to do or say about the Lounge perhaps we can make it do, this winter it may be we must have Joseph's bed in this room before long he is very feeble.
 Dont think Charles could very well fix a ? he does have a very hard time I'm
